e1.content: SQL injection is a web security vulnerability that allows an attacker to interfere with the queries that an application makes to its database.

e2.content: DNS spoofing, also referred to as DNS cache poisoning, is a form of computer security hacking in which corrupt Domain Name System data is introduced into the DNS resolver's cache, causing the name server to return an incorrect result record, e.g. an IP address.

e3.content: Cross-site request forgery (also known as CSRF) is a web security vulnerability that allows an attacker to induce users to perform actions that they do not intend to perform. It allows an attacker to partly circumvent the same origin policy, which is designed to prevent different websites from interfering with each other.

e4.content: A DDoS attack is a malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server by overwhelming the target with a flood of Internet traffic.

e5.content: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) is a client-side code injection attack. The attacker aims to execute malicious scripts in a web browser of the victim by including malicious code in a legitimate web page or web application.

Q5.ques: The multiplicative inverse of 0x95 in AES where m(x)=x8+x4+x3+x+1 is

Q6.ques: How many computation rounds does the simplified AES consists of?

Q7.ques: For the case of Mixed Columns and Inverse Mixed Columns, is it true that b(x) = a-1(x) mod (x4 + 1), where a(x) = {03}x3 + {01}x2 + {01}x + {02} and b(x) = {0B}x3 + {0D}x2 + {09}x + {0E}
Q7.b: False. The expression for a(x) is wrong.
Q7.c: False. The expression for b(x) is wrong.
Q7.d: False. Both a(x) and b(x) are faulty.

Q8.ques: For an input key of size 128 bits constituting all zeros, what is w(7) ?

Q9.ques: On comparing AES with DES, which of the following functions from DES does not have an equivalent AES function?
Q9.d: xor of subkey with function f

Q10.ques:
Which of the following are true:
 i) In the AES key expansion algorithm, the function g() operates on w i+3 
 ii) Perform a one-byte right circular rotation on the argument 4-byte word 
 iii) The round constant follows the formula RC[j] = RC[j − 1]

Q1.ques: __________ is a naming system given to different computers which adapt to human-readable domain names.

Q3.ques: Some security issues might exist owing to misconfigured __________________ which can direct to disclosure of information regarding the domain.

Q4.ques: ______________ is a form of nasty online attack in which a user gets redirects queries to a DNS because of override of system’s TCP/IP settings.

Q6.ques: A ______________ is essentially a text file residing on the server that hosts different domain containing entries for dissimilar resource records.

Q1.ques: As a web application user, what puts you at most risk to fall victim to a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attack ?
Q1.b: Using a web app that is not fully protected by SSL/TLS
Q1.c: Using the "keep me logged in" option offered by web apps

Q2.ques: If you want your web application to defend itself against cross-site scripting attacks that steal session IDs, which cookie attribute is best able to help you ?

Q3.ques: Your web application allows users to download their account statements in PDF format. What is the most secure way to implement this functionality ?
Q3.a: Store all PDFs in an obscure directory on the web server and provide a link to the correct PDF depending on the user.
Q3.b: Generate the PDF on the fly, write it to a temporary directory on the server, and redirect the browser to that location (via 302 response).
Q3.c: Generate the PDF on the fly, store it in memory on the server, and send the bytes of the PDF to the browser directly (via 200 response).
Q3.d: Store the PDFs in a database and retrieve the correct PDF by looking at the identifier/primary key provided in the HTTP request.

Q4.ques: What is one way developers can defend against forced browsing attacks ?
Q4.d: Use a sensible directory naming scheme

Q5.ques: All web applications are vulnerable to CSRF attacks unless there's a specific protection mechanism in place.

Q3.ques: In Caesar cipher, each plain text is replaced by

Q5.ques: A cipher system is said to have perfect secrecy if
Q5.a: Posteriori probability is equal to priori probability
Q5.b: Posteriori probability is greater than priori probability
Q5.c: Posteriori probability is less than priori probability

Q6.ques: The conditions for perfect secrecy are
Q6.a: Only one key transforming message should exist
Q6.b: All keys should be equally likely
Q6.c: One key transforming message to each cipher text & all keys should be equally likely

Q1.ques: SQL injection is an attack in which _________ code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server.

Q2.a: Parameterized data cannot be manipulated by a skilled and determined attacker
Q2.b: Procedure that constructs SQL statements should be reviewed for injection vulnerabilities
Q2.c: The primary form of SQL injection consists of indirect insertion of code

Q3.ques: Which of the following script is an example of SQL injection attack ?
Q3.a: var Shipcity;\n ShipCity = Request.form ("ShipCity");\nvar SQL = "select * from OrdersTable where ShipCity = '" + ShipCity + "'";
Q3.c: var Shipcity;\nvar SQL = "select * from OrdersTable where ShipCity = '" + ShipCity + "'";

Q4.ques: Any user-controlled parameter that gets processed by the application includes vulnerabilities like ___________
Q4.c: Application parameters included as part of the body of a POST request

Q5.a: SQL injection vulnerabilities occur whenever input is used in the construction of an SQL query without being adequately constrained or sanitized
Q5.b: SQL injection allows an attacker to access the SQL servers and execute SQL code under the privileges of the user used to connect to the database
Q5.c: The use of PL-SQL opens the door to these vulnerabilities

Q4.ques: RC4 was built on the sole purpose of generating random bits i.e. to act as a PRNG.

Q5.a: a test to determine whether the number of runs of ones and zeros of various lengths is as expected
Q5.b: a test to detect if a sequence can be significantly compressed without loss of information
Q5.c: a test to determine whether the number of ones and zeros in a sequence is approx the same as in a truly random o/p
Q5.d: a test for the check of evenness in the 1s and 0s

Q6.ques: We should not be able to determine the seed from any previous knowledge of the bits sequence. This is the property of backward unpredictability.

Q7.ques: Forward Unpredictability is a property when the seed is unknown, and the next output bit is the sequence should be unpredictable.

Q8.ques: A rule to check for a large number N being a prime number
Q8.a: by dividing N by every even integer less than N/2
Q8.b: by dividing N by every odd integer less than root(N)
Q8.c: by dividing N by every even integer less than root(N)
Q8.d: by dividing N by every integer less than N/2
